snippet.title: The Simple Architecture of AI Agents
snippet.description:
Building an AI agent is simpler than you think, but this simplicity hides a fundamental shift in software development. The real challenge is not the model, but the architecture you build around it.

Most developers treat Large Language Models (LLMs) like any other API, leading them to build brittle, expensive toys. This guide reveals the professional mental model for agentic engineering: managing a stateless LLM inside a stateful loop that you control.

You'll learn: 

‚Üí Why LLMs are stateless and how the illusion of conversation is created. 

‚Üí The simple while loop structure that gives an AI agent memory and state. 

‚Üí How to implement the Plan-Execute-Response cycle to give agents tools. 

‚Üí The three core engineering challenges: context management, reliability, and cost.

This video is for software developers who want to move beyond simple API calls and understand the fundamental architecture required to build robust, production-ready AI agents.

Subscribe üëâ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCR4rI98w6-MqYoCS6jR9LGg

snippet.title: Context Engineering: The #1 Skill for Building Reliable AI Agents
snippet.description:
Learn the principles of Context Engineering to build reliable AI agents by properly managing the LLM context window, a crucial skill for modern AI engineering.

Your AI application works on simple tests but fails on complex tasks because it forgets instructions, gets confused, and its performance degrades. The problem is not the model, but how you feed it information. This is the core challenge of Context Engineering: actively managing an LLM's short-term memory to ensure it has the right information at the right time. A bigger context window is not a magic solution; mastering its management is the key to building robust and efficient AI systems.

You'll learn:

‚Üí The three silent killers of AI performance: Context Rot, Pollution, and Confusion.
‚Üí Why Context Compaction is a better first step than Summarization for context hygiene.
‚Üí The correct mental model for managing context in multi-agent systems.
‚Üí How to design a Hierarchical Action Space to prevent tool-related confusion.

This video is for software developers and AI engineers who are building LLM-powered applications and struggling with agent reliability and performance on complex, long-running tasks.

Subscribe for more üëâ https://www.youtube.com/@cesarsotovalero?sub_confirmation=1

snippet.title: Why Software Engineers Struggle With AI Systems
snippet.description:
AI agents, LLM systems, and production-grade AI engineering require a different mindset than traditional software development. This video breaks down how to design, evaluate, and scale reliable AI systems beyond prompt tuning.

Most senior engineers don‚Äôt fail at building AI systems because they lack skill. They fail because they apply deterministic thinking to a probabilistic system.

In this video, I break down why traditional software engineering instincts collapse when you start building AI agents. We‚Äôll go beyond prompt tuning and into systems design, evaluation pipelines, and real-world architecture trade-offs that separate demo projects from production systems.

You‚Äôll learn:

‚Üí Why ‚Äúsame input, same output‚Äù is a myth in agentic AI  
‚Üí How vibe-driven development quietly destroys reliability  
‚Üí The hidden latency tax of multi-step agent workflows  
‚Üí Why the best AI systems are often shockingly simple  
‚Üí How to shift from prompting to real orchestration  

If you‚Äôre building AI agents that work in demos but fall apart in production, this video gives you a mental model to engineer for stability, speed, and scale.

üëâ Subscribe for more deep dives into AI engineering, system design, and production ML:  
https://www.youtube.com/@cesarsotovalero?sub_confirmation=1

snippet.title: Is Spec-Driven Development the Future of Software Development?
snippet.description:
AI coding tools, software engineering workflows, and AI agents are changing how specifications, prompts, and requirements shape production systems. This video breaks down Spec-Driven Development (SDD) as a way to engineer reliable software in a world of infinite code.

AI can now write thousands of lines of code in seconds, and that's a big risk. In this video, I break down Spec-Driven Development (SDD), an approach where the specification becomes the real source of truth, and the code becomes a downstream artifact.

You‚Äôll learn:

1. Why most ‚ÄúAI bugs‚Äù are actually argument bugs, not logic bugs  
2. The three levels of SDD (and which one quietly traps engineering teams)  
3. When writing a spec saves months of rework, and when it just wastes time  

If you‚Äôre building with GitHub Copilot, Claude Code, or any AI agent, this video will change how you think about prompts, requirements, and what ‚Äúgood engineering‚Äù actually means in a world of infinite code.

üëâ Subscribe for more deep dives into AI development, system design, and modern software engineering:  youtube.com/@cesarsotovalero?sub_confirmation=1

snippet.title: Data Science in 2026: From Building Models to Owning Systems
snippet.description:
Data science, machine learning, and MLOps are shifting from model building to owning production decision systems (reliability, monitoring, and real business outcomes).

Training a machine learning model is no longer the hard part. Keeping it useful, reliable, and valuable in the real world is. That‚Äôs where the impact is (and that‚Äôs where the paychecks will be).

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí Why shipping a model or dashboard is no longer enough in 2026
‚Üí What ‚Äúoutcome accountability‚Äù means for data and ML roles
‚Üí How ‚Äúmodel problems‚Äù often start as system problems (data quality, pipelines, drift, users)
‚Üí The mindset shift from building artifacts to owning decision systems in production
‚Üí Five principles to stay relevant without burning out

This is for data scientists, ML engineers, analytics engineers, and tech leads who can build models, but want to own end-to-end systems that survive reality (and can be explained in business terms).

snippet.title: Why Creativity Just Became the Most Practical Skill
snippet.description:
Creativity in the age of AI (neuroscience, psychology, boredom, and idea generation) explains what humans still do best and how to train original thinking.

In a world where AI can write, draw, and code, what‚Äôs left for humans? The answer might be creativity. Not inspiration as a personality trait, but a skill you can reliably train.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí How boredom and the Default Mode Network can fuel better ideas
‚Üí Why ‚Äúliquid networks‚Äù and collaboration amplify originality
‚Üí How conceptual blending creates new concepts from old parts
‚Üí Why incubation works (and why forcing output backfires)
‚Üí Practical habits to generate more original ideas on demand

This is for creators, engineers, writers, and curious professionals who feel the pressure to compete with AI output, and want a concrete mental model for creative thinking.

snippet.title: The 7 Papers That Built Modern AI
snippet.description:
The 7 landmark AI research papers behind modern breakthroughs (Word2Vec, Transformers, GPT, RLHF, scaling laws, RAG, and chain-of-thought) explained as one scientific storyline.

Modern AI didn‚Äôt ‚Äúappear‚Äù. It was engineered, paper by paper, with a few ideas that quietly rewired the entire field. This video is the compressed origin story of today‚Äôs LLM era, from embeddings to reasoning.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí Why embeddings (Word2Vec) changed how machines represent meaning
‚Üí Why Transformers became the universal architecture for language and beyond
‚Üí How GPT reframed training as ‚Äúpredict the next token‚Äù at scale
‚Üí Why RLHF made models usable (and why it‚Äôs not just alignment theater)
‚Üí The unintuitive math behind scaling laws and why bigger often wins
‚Üí How RAG reduces hallucinations by grounding generation in retrieval
‚Üí How chain-of-thought unlocked more reliable multi-step reasoning

This is for developers, data scientists, ML engineers, and curious builders who want the mental map of how we got from classic NLP to today‚Äôs LLM systems (without reading 200 pages of papers).

üëâ Subscribe for more: https://www.youtube.com/@cesarsotovalero?sub_confirmation=1

snippet.title: Why LLMs Can‚Äôt Solve Complex Planning Problems
snippet.description:
LLMs and optimization are not the same thing (planning, scheduling, NP-hard search, and why ChatGPT-style models fail without solvers like CP-SAT, CPLEX, or MiniZinc).

One of the biggest misconceptions in AI right now is that Large Language Models (ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini) can solve real optimization and planning problems. They can talk about solutions. That‚Äôs not the same as finding one.

Planning problems (employee rostering, routing, timetabling, job-shop scheduling) live in a different universe from next-token prediction. They are NP-hard, combinatorial, and require search and constraints, not linguistic guesswork.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí Why LLMs fail at planning tasks (and often confidently return invalid schedules)
‚Üí Why ‚Äúreasoning models‚Äù still collapse under combinatorial explosion
‚Üí What tools are actually built for optimization (mathematical programming, constraint solvers, meta-heuristics)
‚Üí Where CPLEX, MiniZinc, Timefold (and similar tools) fit in the real stack
‚Üí How to build hybrid systems where the LLM structures the problem and the solver does the heavy lifting

This is for software engineers, ML engineers, and AI builders who want to ship systems that work in production (and avoid the hype trap of using language models as generic problem solvers).

üëâ Subscribe for more: https://www.youtube.com/@cesarsotovalero?sub_confirmation=1

snippet.title: How Scientists Fool Themselves: 5 Psychological Biases & Their Countermoves
snippet.description:
The 5 most dangerous psychological biases in science (confirmation bias, optimism bias, sunk-cost fallacy, self-serving bias, and groupthink) and how to spot them before they corrupt results.

Most scientists believe psychological bias is something that happens to other people. In reality, it‚Äôs the invisible force shaping every hypothesis, experiment, and ‚Äúsignificant result.‚Äù It doesn‚Äôt just distort conclusions. It quietly selects which conclusions you are even able to see.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí How optimism bias pushes researchers to overestimate evidence and underestimate risk
‚Üí How confirmation bias rigs interpretation (without you noticing)
‚Üí Why self-serving bias rewrites your story after the results are in
‚Üí How sunk-cost fallacy keeps bad ideas alive long after the data says ‚Äústop‚Äù
‚Üí Why groupthink can make smart teams converge on wrong answers

This is for scientists, PhD students, and evidence-driven professionals who want cleaner reasoning, better experiments, and fewer self-inflicted research disasters.

localized.title: How Scientists Fool Themselves: 5 Psychological Biases & Their Countermoves
localized.description:
The 5 most dangerous psychological biases in science (confirmation bias, optimism bias, sunk-cost fallacy, self-serving bias, and groupthink) and how to spot them before they corrupt results.

Most scientists believe psychological bias is something that happens to other people. In reality, it‚Äôs the invisible force shaping every hypothesis, experiment, and ‚Äúsignificant result.‚Äù It doesn‚Äôt just distort conclusions. It quietly selects which conclusions you are even able to see.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí How optimism bias pushes researchers to overestimate evidence and underestimate risk
‚Üí How confirmation bias rigs interpretation (without you noticing)
‚Üí Why self-serving bias rewrites your story after the results are in
‚Üí How sunk-cost fallacy keeps bad ideas alive long after the data says ‚Äústop‚Äù
‚Üí Why groupthink can make smart teams converge on wrong answers

This is for scientists, PhD students, and evidence-driven professionals who want cleaner reasoning, better experiments, and fewer self-inflicted research disasters.

snippet.title: How AI Is Killing the Ad-Funded Internet‚Äôs Business Model
snippet.description:
AI is changing the Internet economy, digital advertising, and how creators, businesses, and search engines survive in a world of AI-powered answer engines.

AI isn‚Äôt just disrupting jobs or generating hype, it‚Äôs quietly dismantling the economic engine of the open web. For 15+ years, the Internet ran on one currency: human attention. Creators published content, search engines delivered traffic, and businesses monetized clicks. But AI-driven answer engines are bypassing websites entirely, and that breaks the ads industry that fuels the web.

In this video, we explore the consequences of this seismic shift:

‚úì Why traffic was never a real ‚Äúvalue‚Äù  
‚úì How AI scrapers are draining the ecosystem  
‚úì What new business models could make the Internet sustainable again  

By the end, you‚Äôll understand not only what‚Äôs at stake, but also how creators, companies, and users could redesign the digital economy before it collapses.

snippet.title: Why Fully Homomorphic Encryption Is the Future of Private Computing
snippet.description:
Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) explained (privacy-preserving computation, encrypted data in use, lattice cryptography, and real tools like Microsoft SEAL and Google HEIR).

What if your data could stay encrypted even while being processed? That‚Äôs the promise of Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE), a breakthrough that could reshape privacy, AI, cloud security, and the future of the internet.

In this video, I‚Äôll break down FHE without drowning you in equations. We‚Äôll focus on the core ideas, the real problem it solves, and why it‚Äôs suddenly becoming a serious topic (with interest from companies like Microsoft, Google, and Apple).

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí What problem FHE solves (and why traditional encryption fails when data is ‚Äúin use‚Äù)
‚Üí How FHE works using simple examples and analogies (no math pain)
‚Üí Why lattice-based cryptography matters (and how it connects to quantum resistance)
‚Üí Where the performance curve is heading (the ‚ÄúMoore‚Äôs Law‚Äù story of FHE)
‚Üí Real-world use cases already running today, plus open-source tools you can try

This is for developers, security engineers, AI builders, and curious learners who want the big picture of privacy-preserving computing (and what it could unlock for a more private internet).

snippet.title: How GPTs are Shaping our Perception of Truth
snippet.description:
How LLMs like GPT shape ‚Äútruth‚Äù online (hallucinations, bias, crowd-consensus effects, epistemic trust) and how to think critically about AI-generated answers.

Search used to route you to sources. LLMs increasingly hand you conclusions. That convenience is exactly why they can reshape what you believe to be true, even when they‚Äôre wrong in confident and subtle ways.

In this video, we explore how GPT-style models influence perception of truth, where their ‚Äúknowledge‚Äù really comes from, and why they‚Äôre powerful yet fallible. We‚Äôll unpack hallucinations, bias, and the crowd-consensus effect, then end with practical habits for engaging with AI outputs without outsourcing your judgment.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí Why the shift from search to AI answers changes epistemic trust
‚Üí How LLMs can look intelligent while still being unreliable
‚Üí Where hallucinations come from (and why they‚Äôre not random glitches)
‚Üí The unexpected biases and consensus effects that distort outputs
‚Üí Practical ways to verify, cross-check, and use LLMs responsibly

This is for developers, students, knowledge workers, and anyone using AI daily who wants a clean mental model of what LLMs are (and aren‚Äôt) so you can rely on them without being quietly misled.

snippet.title: Developer Burnout Explained (7 types of overwhelm and how to beat them)
snippet.description:
Seven types of developer overwhelm explained (context switching, meetings, technical complexity, time pressure) plus practical tactics to prevent burnout and turn stress into focus.

Why do so many skilled software developers feel overwhelmed even in structured, high-paying tech jobs? Because ‚Äúoverwhelm‚Äù isn‚Äôt one thing. It‚Äôs a set of different failure modes that look similar on the surface, but demand different fixes.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí The 7 types of developer overwhelm and how to recognize each one
‚Üí Why meetings and interruptions drain you faster than hard engineering work
‚Üí How organizational chaos and communication overload compound burnout
‚Üí When ‚Äútechnical overwhelm‚Äù is the real issue (and when it‚Äôs a symptom)
‚Üí How some developers convert pressure into clarity without self-gaslighting

This is for software engineers, tech leads, and engineering managers who feel busy all day but still end the week thinking: ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt actually build anything.‚Äù

snippet.title: Embrace AI in your Career and Life (there isn‚Äôt another way)
snippet.description:
AI is reshaping jobs, skills, and society (future of work, automation economics, and what to do next) through the lens of past tech revolutions and what makes this one different.

The rise of Artificial Intelligence (AI) is more than a tech trend. It is a structural change to how value is created, how labor is priced, and how careers evolve. The uncomfortable question is whether AI liberates us from the 9-to-5, or just automates the pressure and calls it progress.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí Why ‚Äútechnological salvation‚Äù is often a mirage (and what history actually shows)
‚Üí What computers promised but failed to deliver (and why AI might repeat the pattern)
‚Üí How AI shifts jobs and skills, not just tasks (and what to invest in)
‚Üí The economics of labor in the age of AI (wages, productivity, leverage)
‚Üí A practical mindset shift for using AI as a tool, not a trap
‚Üí Where AI could create real upside (health, climate, science) if we steer it well

This is for students, developers, professionals, and curious people who want a grounded mental model of the AI revolution (and concrete ways to adapt without panic or hype).

snippet.title: Why AI will NOT replace Software Engineers (for now)
snippet.description:
Will AI replace software engineers (LLMs, coding assistants, real-world development work, and what humans still uniquely do) beyond the headlines and hype.

AI systems are getting scary-good at cognitive tasks, and LLMs can write code fast. So are software engineering jobs actually at risk, or is this another wave of sensational headlines flattening a complex reality?

In this video, we unpack what ‚Äúsoftware engineering‚Äù really is (beyond typing code), where AI genuinely helps in day-to-day development, and where it still falls short when the work demands creativity, judgment, ownership, and attention to the small human details that make systems usable and safe.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí What the headlines get wrong about ‚ÄúAI replacing engineers‚Äù
‚Üí The essence of software engineering (and why code is the easy part)
‚Üí Where AI helps today (implementation, refactoring, docs, tests, debugging support)
‚Üí Where AI still struggles (ambiguity, trade-offs, product context, accountability)
‚Üí Whether juniors are more exposed (and how to become ‚ÄúAI-leveraged‚Äù instead)
‚Üí Practical ways to use AI as a force multiplier without losing engineering rigor

This is for developers, students, tech leads, and anyone anxious about the future of coding who wants a grounded view of AI‚Äôs real capabilities (and a strategy that doesn‚Äôt rely on denial or panic).

üëâ Subscribe for more: https://www.youtube.com/@cesarsotovalero?sub_confirmation=1

snippet.title: Speaking Imperfect English Can Transform Your Life

Learning English as a non-native speaker changed my life (IELTS, academia, career growth) from Cuba to Europe, plus practical tips to improve your English fast.

I came from a small town in Cuba where access to basic needs was severely limited. One day I decided to teach myself English and signed up for the IELTS test. Ten years later, I live in one of Europe‚Äôs most developed cities, pursuing an academic and professional path that once felt impossible.

This video isn‚Äôt just about learning a second language. It‚Äôs about breaking barriers, expanding your options, and using English as leverage for education, research, and career growth (even when the odds are not on your side).

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí Why English matters for opportunities (especially in science and academia)
‚Üí How English became the default language of research and global work
‚Üí My story of deciding to learn English (what worked and what didn‚Äôt)
‚Üí What the IELTS test was like and how I prepared

snippet.title: The AI Secret: Why Predictive Machine Learning Still Rules The Real World
snippet.description:
The buzz around AI has been skyrocketing, yet many misconceptions persist about its true capabilities today. This talk dives into lesser-known facts about AI, covering its origins, current real-world applications, and why predictive Machine Learning remains the most impactful AI technology. From AI's theoretical beginnings in 1943 to its practical applications in the financial sector, this talk will offer a fresh perspective on AI‚Äôs real-world value and its future.

snippet.title: Learning Software Development Is Not a Sprint: Top Performers Are Built Over Time
snippet.description:
Learning to code fast is a myth (Java, C++, Python), and real software engineering mastery comes from deliberate practice, patience, and a long-term learning strategy.

So many books and courses promise you can master Java, C++, or Python in a few days. The uncomfortable truth is that proficiency is built, not downloaded. Rushing doesn‚Äôt speed up learning. It mostly speeds up frustration, shallow knowledge, and burnout.

In this video, we debunk the ‚Äúlearn software development quickly‚Äù fantasy and explain why real expertise takes time. We‚Äôll cover what deliberate practice actually means, why copying tutorials feels productive but often isn‚Äôt, and how to learn in a way that compounds over months and years.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí Why ‚Äúlearn to code in a day‚Äù sets you up for fragile skills
‚Üí The difference between familiarity and competence (and why it tricks you)
‚Üí How deliberate practice builds real ability (not just motivation)
‚Üí How learning from other developers accelerates progress the right way
‚Üí A long-term approach that makes coding feel easier over time

This is for beginners, self-taught developers, and early-career engineers who feel pressure to ‚Äúcatch up fast‚Äù and want a strategy that actually works (without the motivational poster lies).

üëâ Subscribe for more: https://www.youtube.com/@cesarsotovalero?sub_confirmation=1

üì∫ RESOURCES

‚Üí Peter Norvig (Teach Yourself Programming in Ten Years): http://norvig.com/21-days.html

snippet.title: Cargo Cult in Computer Science: An Uncomfortable Truth for Researchers
snippet.description:
The reproducibility crisis in computer science explained through Feynman‚Äôs ‚ÄúCargo Cult Science‚Äù (research rigor, pseudoscience traps, and practical steps for transparent, reproducible work).

Have you ever heard about the reproducibility crisis in computer science research? In this video, we revisit Richard Feynman‚Äôs famous ‚ÄúCargo Cult Science‚Äù message and why it still describes modern research failure modes with uncomfortable accuracy.

We break down how academic pressure, weak methodology, and ‚Äúlooks scientific‚Äù behaviors can lead to poor science and even pseudoscience. You‚Äôll also get concrete guidance to make your work more rigorous, transparent, and reproducible (so your results survive contact with reality, not just peer review).

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí What ‚ÄúCargo Cult Science‚Äù really means and why it shows up in CS research
‚Üí How pseudoscience and bad incentives creep into legitimate labs
‚Üí Why reproducibility fails (data, code, environments, reporting, evaluation)
‚Üí The academic trap (publish pressure, novelty bias, and selective reporting)
‚Üí Practical steps to improve rigor, transparency, and reproducibility

This is for PhD students, researchers, and research-minded engineers who want their work to be trustworthy, repeatable, and genuinely useful (not just statistically significant).

üëâ Subscribe for more: https://www.youtube.com/@cesarsotovalero?sub_confirmation=1

üì∫ RESOURCES

‚Üí Feynman‚Äôs commencement speech (PDF): http://calteches.library.caltech.edu/51/2/CargoCult.pdf
‚Üí ACM Queue (‚ÄúRepeat, Reproduce, Replicate‚Äù): https://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=3674499
‚Üí 2014 report (‚ÄúMeasuring Reproducibility in Computer Systems Research‚Äù): https://cs.brown.edu/~sk/Memos/Examining-Reproducibility/measuring-tr.pdf

snippet.title: The Silent Crisis of Software Bloat
snippet.description:
Software bloat explained (millions of lines of code, dependencies, reuse, hardware evolution) plus causes, real costs, and practical solutions inspired by Wirth and modern research.

Software powers everything around us, but behind every polished UI there‚Äôs a growing problem: software bloat. Modern systems have ballooned to millions of lines of code, and it‚Äôs not just ‚Äúdevelopers being lazy‚Äù. It‚Äôs the compound effect of reuse, dependency sprawl, incentives, and hardware getting faster enough to hide the pain (until it doesn‚Äôt).

In this video, I break down the causes, consequences, and realistic solutions to software bloat. I also connect the dots to ideas that computer scientists like Niklaus Wirth warned about decades ago, and share lessons from my own PhD research on debloating and dependencies.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí Why software exploded in size (and why it keeps compounding)
‚Üí How reuse and third-party dependencies quietly create bloat
‚Üí Where hardware evolution masked inefficiency (and what it cost us)
‚Üí The real price of bloat (security, performance, maintenance, reliability)
‚Üí Practical paths forward (debloating, dependency discipline, lean design)

This is for software engineers, tech leads, security-minded developers, and anyone building systems at scale who wants to reduce complexity without pretending we can go back to 1975.

üëâ Subscribe for more: https://www.youtube.com/@cesarsotovalero?sub_confirmation=1

üì∫ RESOURCES
‚Üí Watch next (PhD thesis defense, Debloating Java Dependencies): https://youtu.be/Ub684G_aM5Q?si=QK7r-00QDwl4zLXc
‚Üí Talk (Joe Armstrong, ‚ÄúThe Mess We‚Äôre In‚Äù): https://youtu.be/lKXe3HUG2l4
‚Üí Talk (Dylan Beattie, ‚ÄúSoftware Is Not Art Anymore‚Äù): https://youtu.be/VA1eIVVsVhY?si=ra4k08IYdMGctSKP
‚Üí Blog post (Why Debloating Third-Party Software?): https://www.cesarsotovalero.net/blog/why-debloating-third-party-software.html
‚Üí Niklaus Wirth (A Plea for Lean Software): https://doi.ieeecomputersociety.org/10.1109/2.348001
‚Üí IEEE Spectrum (Why Bloat Is Still Software‚Äôs Biggest Vulnerability): https://spectrum.ieee.org/lean-software-development
‚Üí Curated papers (bloat and debloating): https://www.cesarsotovalero.net/software-debloating-papers.html

snippet.title: How to Peer-Review Research Papers Like an ‚ÄúExpert‚Äù
snippet.description:
How to peer-review research papers efficiently and fairly (journal and conference peer-review workflow, quick triage, detailed review, and a practical review template).

Over the last few years, I‚Äôve peer-reviewed 10+ papers for top journals and conferences (and I‚Äôve also been on the receiving end of tough reviews as a PhD student). The biggest lesson is simple: great peer review is not about being harsh. It‚Äôs about being clear, useful, and reproducible in your judgment.

In this video, I share my personal approach to writing efficient and effective peer reviews. Whether you‚Äôre reviewing for the first time or refining your process, you‚Äôll get a repeatable workflow for evaluating research with confidence, without wasting hours or turning the review into a vague opinion piece.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí How peer review actually works (roles, expectations, and what editors want)
‚Üí How to respond to a review invitation and quickly assess fit and scope
‚Üí A ‚Äúquick review‚Äù triage method to spot fatal issues early
‚Üí A ‚Äúdetailed review‚Äù method that produces actionable feedback
‚Üí What makes a review good vs. bad (and how to avoid common reviewer mistakes)
‚Üí The peer-review template I use to stay fast, fair, and consistent

This is for PhD students, early-career researchers, and engineers reviewing academic papers who want a practical system for peer reviewing that helps authors improve and helps venues make better decisions.

snippet.title: Revisiting Ken Thompson‚Äôs Turing Award Lecture ‚ÄúReflections on Trusting Trust‚Äù
snippet.description:
Ken Thompson‚Äôs ‚ÄúReflections on Trusting Trust‚Äù explained (Trojan Horse compilers, self-replicating backdoors, and why supply chain security breaks the ‚Äújust read the source‚Äù myth).

Ken Thompson‚Äôs Turing Award lecture ‚ÄúReflections on Trusting Trust‚Äù is one of the most chilling ideas in cybersecurity history: you can backdoor a compiler so it silently reinserts the backdoor into every future version of itself. The punchline is brutal. The source code can look clean while the binary stays compromised.

In this video, we walk through the core mechanism behind the Trojan Horse compiler attack, why it‚Äôs practically undetectable with source review alone, and how this connects to modern software supply chain threats.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí The real problem of software trust (source vs. binary)
‚Üí Thompson‚Äôs claim and why it still holds in 2026
‚Üí How the self-reinserting compiler backdoor works
‚Üí What quines (self-replicating code) have to do with the attack
‚Üí Why this is a supply chain nightmare (and what it implies today)

This is for software engineers, security practitioners, and anyone who thinks ‚Äúopen source means safe‚Äù who wants a sharper model of trust, compilers, and the limits of code review.

üëâ Subscribe for more: https://www.youtube.com/@cesarsotovalero?sub_confirmation=1

üì∫ RESOURCES
‚Üí Original paper (1984, ‚ÄúReflections on Trusting Trust‚Äù): https://doi.org/10.1145/358198.358210
‚Üí My blog post (deep dive): https://www.cesarsotovalero.net/blog/revisiting-ken-thompson-reflection-on-trusting-trust.html

snippet.title: The Last Paper‚Äôs Myth: PhD Student Expectations vs. Reality at the End of a PhD
snippet.description:
The ‚Äúlast paper‚Äù myth in the final PhD year explained (academic pressure, thesis expectations vs. reality, and practical strategies to protect balance and finish strong).

Finishing a PhD often comes with a specific kind of pressure: ‚Äújust one more paper.‚Äù It sounds reasonable. It can also quietly sabotage your final year by stretching timelines, draining motivation, and turning the finish line into a moving target.

In this video, I break down what I call the last paper‚Äôs myth, why it shows up in so many PhD programs, and how to navigate the expectations versus the realities of wrapping up your thesis. I also share actionable strategies to manage pressure, maintain work-life balance, and finish your PhD without sacrificing your health or your future.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí Why the ‚Äúone more paper‚Äù push happens (and why it‚Äôs often a conflict of interests)
‚Üí The gap between end-of-PhD expectations and real-world constraints
‚Üí How pressure affects productivity, focus, and mental health near the finish line
‚Üí Practical strategies to counter the pressure and protect your timeline
‚Üí Why this pattern also shows up in corporate environments (and how to recognize it)

This is for PhD students in their final year (and early-career researchers) who feel stuck between ‚ÄúI should be done‚Äù and ‚ÄúI‚Äôm being asked for more,‚Äù and want a clearer way to decide what‚Äôs worth doing.

snippet.title: How to Overcome Writer's Block When Preparing a Research Paper
snippet.description:
How to overcome writer‚Äôs block in academic writing (research papers, PhD workflow, drafting strategies, and practical tactics to finish without perfectionism).

Struggling with writer‚Äôs block while writing research papers? I‚Äôve been there too. The uncomfortable truth is that writer‚Äôs block is rarely a ‚Äúlack of ideas‚Äù. It‚Äôs usually a workflow problem: starting from a blank page, aiming for perfection too early, and trying to write and edit at the same time.

In this video, I share the strategies that helped me push through writer‚Äôs block during my PhD in Computer Science. We‚Äôll cover how to structure the paper early, write imperfect drafts on purpose, use figures and results to create momentum, and refine later when the raw material actually exists.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí A simple structure-first approach to start a research paper faster
‚Üí How adding figures and results early reduces blank-page paralysis
‚Üí How to paraphrase recurring content without getting stuck rewriting
‚Üí Why ‚Äúdraft first, refine later‚Äù is a productivity superpower
‚Üí A practical rule: either write something, or consciously do nothing
‚Üí Mental tricks that make the finished task feel real (and doable)

This is for PhD students, researchers, and academic writers who feel stuck in the loop of overthinking, procrastinating, and perfectionism and want a repeatable way to keep moving.

snippet.title: Debloating Java Dependencies
snippet.description:
My PhD Defense
June 1st, 2023

Link to the full PhD thesis: https://www.cesarsotovalero.net/files/thesis/cesar-fulltext.pdf
Link to the slides: https://www.cesarsotovalero.net/files/thesis/slides/cesar-phd-defense.pptx

# Summary

Software systems have a natural tendency to grow in size and complexity. A part of this growth comes with the addition of new features or bug fixes, while another part is due to useless code that accumulates over time. This phenomenon, known as "software bloat," increases with the practice of reusing software dependencies, which has exceeded the capacity of human developers to efficiently manage them. Software bloat in third-party dependencies presents a multifaceted challenge for application development, encompassing issues of security, performance, and maintenance. To address these issues, researchers have developed software debloating techniques that automatically remove unnecessary code.

Despite significant progress has been made in the realm of software debloating, the pervasive issue of dependency bloat warrants special attention. In this thesis, we contribute to the field of software debloating by proposing novel techniques specifically targeting dependencies in the Java ecosystem. First, we investigate the growth of completely unused software dependencies, which we call "bloated dependencies.''  We propose a technique to automatically detect and remove bloated dependencies in Java projects built with Maven. We empirically study the usage status of dependencies in the Maven Central repository and remove bloated dependencies in mature Java projects. We demonstrate that once a bloated dependency is detected, it can be safely removed as its future usage is unlikely.

Second, we focus on dependencies that are only partially used. We introduce a technique to specialize these dependencies in Java projects based on their actual usage. Our approach systematically identifies the subset of functionalities within each dependency that is sufficient to build the project and removes the rest. We demonstrate that our dependency specialization approach can halve the project classes to dependency classes ratio. Last, we assess the impact of debloating projects with respect to client applications that reuse them. We present a novel coverage-based debloating technique that determines which class members in Java libraries and their dependencies are necessary for their clients. Our debloating technique effectively decreases the size of debloated libraries while preserving the essential functionalities required to successfully build their clients.

My Blog: https://www.cesarsotovalero.net/blog
My GitHub: https://github.com/cesarsotovalero
My Twitter: https://twitter.com/cesarsotovalero
My LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/cesarsotovalero

#phdthesis #computerscience #softwareengineering #softwaredebloating

snippet.title: Coverage-Based Debloating for Java Bytecode
snippet.description:
Presentation at ESEC/FSE 2022.

Read the paper https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/3546948
Read about the ESEC/FSE Conference Journal First Track https://2022.esec-fse.org/track/fse-2022-journal-first#programming 

# Summary

Software bloat is code that is packaged in an application but is actually not necessary to run the application. The presence of software bloat is an issue for security, for performance, and for maintenance. In this paper, we introduce a novel technique for debloating, which we call coverage-based debloating. We implement the technique for one single language: Java bytecode. We leverage a combination of state-of-the-art Java bytecode coverage tools to precisely capture what parts of a project and its dependencies are used when running with a specific workload. Then, we automatically remove the parts that are not covered to generate a debloated version of the project. We succeed in debloating 211 library versions from a dataset of 94 unique open-source Java libraries. The debloated versions are syntactically correct and preserve their original behavior according to the workload. Our results indicate that 68.3% of the libraries‚Äô bytecode and 20.3% of their total dependencies can be removed through coverage-based debloating.

For the first time in the literature on software debloating, we assess the utility of debloated libraries concerning client applications that reuse them. We select 988 client projects that either have a direct reference to the debloated library in their source code or which test suite covers at least one class of the libraries that we debloat. Our results show that 81.5% of the clients with at least one test that uses the library successfully compile and pass their test suite when the original library is replaced by its debloated version.

My GitHub: https://github.com/cesarsotovalero
My Twitter: https://twitter.com/cesarsotovalero

Our results indicate that 68.3% of the libraries‚Äô bytecode and 20.3% of their total dependencies can be removed through coverage-based debloating.

For the first time in the literature on software debloating, we assess the utility of debloated libraries concerning client applications that reuse them. We select 988 client projects that either have a direct reference to the debloated library in their source code or which test suite covers at least one class of the libraries that we debloat. Our results show that 81.5% of the clients with at least one test that uses the library successfully compile and pass their test suite when the original library is replaced by its debloated version.

snippet.title: Reasons to Do a PhD in Computer Science
snippet.description:
7 pragmatic reasons to pursue a PhD in Computer Science (research career, curiosity, networking, differentiation, personal growth, ownership, and global mobility).

Starting a PhD in Computer Science is a serious decision that can reshape your life. It‚Äôs not just ‚Äúmore school‚Äù. It‚Äôs a multi-year commitment that trades short-term certainty for long-term leverage, if you know what you‚Äôre optimizing for.

In this video, I break down seven pragmatic reasons to choose this path, based on real incentives and real outcomes (not academic romance). If you‚Äôre on the fence, this will help you think clearly about what a PhD can unlock and what it will demand from you.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Üí How a PhD can feed intellectual curiosity in a structured way
‚Üí What it takes to become a professional researcher (beyond reading papers)
‚Üí How PhD life builds a career network that compounds for years
‚Üí Why the credential can differentiate you (when used strategically)
‚Üí How the challenge reshapes your confidence and problem-solving
‚Üí What it means to truly own your work and ideas
‚Üí How a PhD can increase mobility (including emigrating) through opportunity

This is for students, software engineers, and early-career professionals considering a PhD in CS who want practical reasons, real trade-offs, and a clearer decision framework.

snippet.title: The Software Supply Chain
snippet.description:
Read the related blog post: https://www.cesarsotovalero.net/blog/the-software-supply-chain.html

0:00 Introduction
0:13 Problem definition
1:15 People in the loop
1:47 Problem & Solution
2:01 Production environment
4:02 Maintenance & Support
5:55 Example
6:44 Mitigation
7:29 Conclusion

# Summary

The software supply chain comprises all the technology involved in shipping a piece of code from development to its deployment in a production environment. Several actors and different technologies participate in this complex process, e.g., developers, IDEs, compilers, package managers, a so on. The success or failure of a software product depends largely on many external components that are not directly controlled by the organizations in charge of delivering software products to their clients. This situation poses several security and maintenance risks for both software suppliers and customers. Thereby, maintaining a secure and efficient software supply chain is critical today, where open-source has become ubiquitous in the software production landscape. In this video, I take a close look at this phenomenon from a software engineering perspective.

snippet.title: A Longitudinal Analysis of Bloated Java Dependencies
snippet.description:
Presented at ESEC/FSE 2021.

Read the paper https://dl.acm.org/doi/pdf/10.1145/3468264.3468589
Read about the ESEC/FSE conference https://2021.esec-fse.org/track/fse-2021-papers

# Summary of the paper

We study the evolution and impact of bloated dependencies in a single software ecosystem: Java/Maven. Bloated dependencies are third-party libraries that are packaged in the application binary but are not needed to run the application. We analyze the history of 435 Java projects. This historical data includes 48,469 distinct dependencies, which we study across a total of 31,515 versions of Maven dependency trees. Bloated dependencies steadily increase over time, and 89.2% of the direct dependencies that are bloated remain bloated in all subsequent versions of the studied projects. This empirical evidence suggests that developers can safely remove a bloated dependency. We further report novel insights regarding the unnecessary maintenance efforts induced by bloat. We find that 22% of dependency updates performed by developers are made on bloated dependencies, and that Dependabot suggests a similar ratio of updates on bloated dependencies.

snippet.title: Automatically Revealing Bloated Software Dependencies in Maven Projects
snippet.description:
Talk presented at FOSDEM 2021

Read the related paper https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007/s10664-020-09914-8.pdf
Read more about FOSDEM https://fosdem.org/2021

# Summary 

The talk introduces DepClean, an open-source tool we developed to automatically determine the presence of bloated dependencies in Maven artifacts. DepClean performs a deep static analysis of the dependency network and suggests direct and transitive dependencies to be removed or excluded. Given an application and its build file, DepClean collects the complete dependency tree (the list of dependencies declared in the pom.xml and transitive dependencies) and analyzes the bytecode of the artifact and all its dependencies to determine the presence of bloated dependencies. DepClean also generates a clean variant of the build file in which bloated dependencies are removed.

This talk focuses on one specific type of software dependency: bloated dependencies. They are libraries packaged with the application's compiled code but not necessary to build and execute the application. In other words, they are libraries declared as dependencies in a build file, which can be removed from the file, and the build still successfully passes. As a consequence of bloated dependencies, the binary file includes more code than necessary. An artificially large binary is an issue when the application is sent over the network (e.g., web applications) or is deployed on small devices (e.g., embedded systems). In addition, bloated dependencies embed vulnerable code that can be exploited while being actually useless for the application. Overall, bloated dependencies needlessly increase the difficulty of managing and evolving software applications.

We present our analysis of 9639 Java artifacts hosted on Maven Central, including 723444 dependency relationships. Our key result is as follows: 2,7% of the dependencies directly declared are bloated, 15,4% of the inherited dependencies are bloated, and 57% of the transitive dependencies of the studied artifacts are bloated. Based on these results, we distill and discuss two possible causes: the cascade of unwanted transitive dependencies induced by direct dependencies and the multi-module Maven projects' dependency heritage mechanism.

Our qualitative assessment of DepClean involves 30 notable open-source projects. For each project, we used DepClean to generate a pom.xml file without bloated dependencies and submitted the changes as a pull request to the project. Notably, our work yielded 21 merged pull requests by open-source developers, and 140 bloated dependencies were removed. In summary, our results indicate that developers pay attention to their dependencies when they are notified of the problem, which stresses the need to engineer, i.e., analyze, maintain, and test POM files.
